TEXT:
Chief Complaint: Nonverbal
   24 Hour Events:
   - attempted cardioversion x2, did not convert with shock, but did
   convert after transtracheal injection of lidocaine prior to intubation
   - nasal intubation done successfully
   - in and out of flutter, maintained MAP's in 70's minimum, was in
   flutter most of the night with unaffected pressures
   - amiodarone load started
   - swan showed RV tracing, repositioned
   - placed OGT to decompress
   - SVO2 remained >70
   - increased milrinone, continued dopamine
   - started lasix gtt - had good UOP during day (>70cc/hr) which
   decreased in late afternoon down to 30cc/hr, titrated up gtt to 15cc/hr
   and then to 20mg/hr as patient put out well (100cc/hr) but was still
   net positive
   - spoke with family regarding current treatment and likely multiple day
   stay in CCU - wife, daughters and mother
   - [**Name2 (NI) 6180**] CK flat, trop 0.02, MB negative
   - decreased FiO2 to 40%, tolerated well
   - LFT's and coags trending down
   - 10pm #'s with CO of 6 and CI of 3 (about the same all day)
   Allergies:
   Tegretol (Oral) (Carbamazepine)
   Unknown;
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Infusions:
   Heparin Sodium - 1,550 units/hour
   Amiodarone - 0.5 mg/min
   Dopamine - 2.5 mcg/Kg/min
   Propofol - 30 mcg/Kg/min

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old male admitted to the ICU for suspected cardiogenic shock. They have been unresponsive and nonverbal since admission. The patient experienced episodes of atrial fibrillation throughout the night but maintained adequate mean arterial pressures. A transtracheal injection of lidocaine was given prior to nasal intubation, which successfully converted the patient from atrial fibrillation to normal sinus rhythm. Amiodarone was started as a load dose. A swan-Ganz catheter was repositioned, and an oxygenation guidewire was placed to decompress the right ventricle. The patient's mixed venous oxygen saturation remained above 70%. Milrinone and dopamine infusions were increased. Lasix was started, and fluid balance was closely monitored. The patient's troponin T levels were negative, and creatine kinase levels were flat. Lactic acid levels were slightly elevated. There were no new changes in the review of systems.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient is currently in cardiogenic shock, which can lead to inadequate blood flow and oxygen supply to vital organs.
2. Atrial fibrillation: The patient has been experiencing episodes of atrial fibrillation, which can increase the risk of clot formation and potential embolic events.
3. Respiratory complications: Due to mechanical ventilation and endotracheal intubation, the patient may develop ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) or

   Assessment and Plan
   53yo male with history of obesity, OSA, and depression who p/w
   increasing SOB x5d and found to have 3+ MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 4298**] TTE with
   hemodynamics consistent with cardiogenic shock. Now s/p intubation and
   cardioversion x1.
   .
   # Cardiogenic shock: Suspect [**3-20**] MR given acute onset 5d ago and no
   known hx of MR, but given elevated RIGHT sided pressures there is some
   suggestion that this might be a chronic process. Depressed EF may be
   partially due to rhythm disturbance. Patient likely had chronic process
   that was exacerbated by several days of Aflutter that precipitated
   cardiogenic shock. CI improved up to 2.4. Warm extremities reassuring
   that shock is improving on Milrinone, Levophed and Dopamine. Failed
   cardioversion yesterday. LFTs improving but renal function unchanged
   suggesting possible component of ATN. Bordeline high temperatures
   likely reflect improving cardiogenic shock rather than sepsis. Elevated
   PA and PCWP with low pulmonary vascular resistance further support
   cardiogenic shock.
   - Try to d/c Dopamine today
   - Continue Milrinone
   - Lasix gtt for diuresis given fluid overload
   - Monitor Fick Q change of shift and with change in clinical status
   .
   # Atrial Flutter: S/p 2 failed cardioversions. Patient did convert for
   some time yesterday, but did go back into flutter indicating that
   patient will likely require more improvement in volume status prior to
   being able to maintain NSR. Plan to continue amiodarone and try to
   improve volume status with lasix and diuril to help improve RA
   geometry.
   - Continue Amiodarone
   - Continue heparin gtt
   - Plan to use lasix and diuril for goal I/O negative 500 cc to 1L. Will
   minimize IV intake as much as possible.
   - EP consult tomorrow re: possible need for ablation
   .
   # Coronaries: Biomarkers flat. ROMI complete.
   ASA 325
   # Respiratory failure: Intubated [**7-9**] peri-cardioversion. Hypoxic
   likely due to medication (ativan) and pulmonary edema. Since fluid
   status has not been improved will defer extubation for now. Became
   tachypnic with SBT today.
   - Continue PS ventilation 12/5
   .
   # Abdominal distention: KUB unremarkable. NG tube with mild to moderate
   output. [**Month (only) 11**] be functional ileus in setting of sepsis and depressive
   agents.
   - Continue NG to low suction
   .
   # Transaminitis: suspect shock liver. LFTs improving. INR elevated but
   stable.
   .  Trend daily INR, glucose, and ALT/AST.
   .
   # ARF: Suspect ATN in setting of cariogenic shock as noted above. Since
   Cr has not improved with better hemodynamics, I assume more likely ATN
   - try to augment cardiac output.
   - renal dose meds
   - if worsens, will d/w renal
   # Hyponatremia: suspect [**3-20**] cardiogenic shock.  Total body up but renal
   perfusion low.
   .
   # FEN: NPO for now.  No TFs given NG output.
   .
   # ACCESS: Cordis with Swan and IJ access. A line. Peripherals
   .
   # Proph: Hep gtt, bowel regimen, HISS
   .
   # Pain control: appears comfortable
   .
   # Code: full
   .
   # Contact; Wife [**Telephone/Fax (1) 6146**] is HCP
   .
   # Dispo: CCU
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:  ISS. No po intake at this time.
   Lines:
   18 Gauge - [**2124-7-9**] 01:10 AM
   Arterial Line - [**2124-7-9**] 04:12 AM
   PA Catheter - [**2124-7-9**] 05:30 AM
   Cordis/Introducer - [**2124-7-9**] 06:55 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: heparin gtt
   Stress ulcer: ppi
   VAP:  per protocol
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition: CCU care for now
Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 53-year-old male with a history of obesity, obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), and depression. He presented with increasing shortness of breath over the past five days and was found to have moderate to severe mitral regurgitation (MR) on transthoracic echocardiography (TTE), along with hemodynamics consistent with cardiogenic shock. The patient underwent intubation and cardioversion, but failed cardioversion yesterday. He is currently on multiple inotropic medications and diuretics for fluid overload.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient's elevated right-sided pressures and depressed ejection fraction suggest a chronic process that may have been exacerbated by atrial flutter. This condition can lead to decreased tissue perfusion and organ dysfunction.
2. Atrial Flutter: Despite two failed cardioversions, the patient converted to normal sinus rhythm temporarily but then reverted back to atrial flutter. Further improvement in volume status is necessary before attempting to maintain normal sinus rhythm. The patient will continue on amiodarone and lasix for volume management.
3. Coronary Artery Disease: Although biomarkers are flat, there is a suspicion of underlying coronary artery disease given the patient's risk factors and symptoms. Further evaluation may be required.
4. Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation due to hypoxia and pulmonary edema. Extubation will be considered once the patient's fluid status

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 53-year-old male with a history of obesity, obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), and depression. He presented with increasing shortness of breath for five days and was found to have significant mitral regurgitation (MR) on echocardiography. The patient is currently in cardiogenic shock and has been intubated and cardioverted once.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient is suspected to have cardiogenic shock due to acute onset of MR and elevated right-sided pressures. Depressed left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) may be partially due to rhythm disturbance. The patient likely had a chronic process that was exacerbated by several days of atrial flutter, leading to cardiogenic shock.

2. Atrial Flutter: The patient has been in atrial flutter and failed two cardioversions. Conversion to normal sinus rhythm (NSR) is planned after improving the patient's volume status with Lasix and Diuril to help improve right atrial (RA) geometry. Amiodarone will be continued, and heparin gtt will also be continued.

3. Coronary Artery Disease: Biomarkers for coronary artery disease are flat, indicating no significant acute coronary syndrome.

4. Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated and has been since peri-cardioversion. Hypoxia is likely due to medication (ativan) and pulmonary edema. Since fluid status

   Assessment and Plan
   53yo male with history of obesity, OSA, and depression who p/w
   increasing SOB x5d and found to have 3+ MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 4298**] TTE with
   hemodynamics consistent with cardiogenic shock. Now s/p intubation and
   cardioversion x1.
   .
   # Cardiogenic shock: Suspect [**3-20**] MR given acute onset 5d ago and no
   known hx of MR, but given elevated RIGHT sided pressures there is some
   suggestion that this might be a chronic process.
   .  Tachycardia likely compensatory to increase CO.  EF is depressed
   globally without regional wall motion abnl so less likely ACS.  Acute
   viral cardiomyopathy unlikely given lack of fevers, B sx.  Tamponade
   unlikely given none seen on echo.
   - treat acute MR [**First Name (Titles) 1187**] [**Last Name (Titles) 6145**] tachycardia.  Will try levophed for
   inotropy and will titrate to changes in UOP and CI.  Reassess 1h after
   starting and if no improvement, will consider alternative options.
   - If afterload increases, will try nitroprusside to improve LV forward
   flow.
   - If heart rate slows, will try dobutamine
   - If hemodynamically unstable or resp compromise, will d/w cards team
   for consideration of urgent balloon pump
   .
   # Cards Valves: as above.  Await official read of echo in am.  Consider
   TEE.  If acute MR confirmed, will d/w cards and CT [**Doctor First Name **]
   .
   # Cards Pump: depressed globally.  augment as above
   .
   # Cards vasc: has delayed RWP on EKG but CE negative.
   - ASA 325
   - complete ROMI
   - consider eval of coronaries if goes to cath for balloon
   .
   # Cards rhythm: aflutter.  Will tolerate HR to 130 for increased CO.
   If rises and unstable, will do cardioversion.
   - hold nodal agents
   .
   # Transaminitis: suspect shock liver vs congestion from cardiogenic
   shock.  Trend daily INR, glucose, and ALT/AST.  Will d/w liver c/s team
   .
   # ARF: Suspect prerenal from poor forward flow vs ATN from hypotension.
   - try to augment cardiac output.
   - check renal lytes
   - if worsens, will d/w renal
   .
   # ID: no clear source of infection.  Received ceftriaxone in ED.  Only
   small ascites so no para overnight.  Will culture elsewhere
   - hold abx
   .
   # Anion gap acidosis: likely from lactate production.  Delta/delta -2
   so no non-gap.
   - check ABG and repeat lactate
   .
   # OSA: will do bipap if stable for sleep
   .
   # Psych: will confirm dosages of meds in am and restart then
   .
   # Hyponatremia: suspect [**3-20**] cardiogenic shock.  Total body up but renal
   perfusion low.
   .
   # FEN: NPO for now.  No IVF given CVP up and risks going into lungs
   .
   # ACCESS: CVL.  obtain Aline
   .
   # Proph: SQH, bowel regimen, HISS
   .
   # Pain control: monitor low back pain
   .
   # Code: full
   .

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 53-year-old male with a history of obesity, obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), and depression. He presented with increasing shortness of breath over five days and was found to have moderate-to-severe mitral regurgitation (MR) on echocardiography. The patient's hemodynamics were consistent with cardiogenic shock, and he underwent intubation and cardioversion.

The patient's condition remains critical, with ongoing management focused on treating acute MR, supporting cardiac output, and addressing associated complications. He is currently in cardiogenic shock, likely due to severe MR, and has depressed global left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) without regional wall motion abnormality. Acute viral cardiomyopathy and cardiac tamponade have been ruled out.

The patient's tachycardia is believed to be compensatory, aiming to increase cardiac output. Inotropy is being provided using levophed, with titration based on urine output (UOP) and cardiac index (CI). If there is no improvement, alternative options will be considered. Nitroprusside may be used to improve left ventricular forward flow if afterload increases. Dobutamine may be considered if the heart rate slows. In case of hemodynamic instability or respiratory compromise, an urgent balloon pump may be discussed with the cardiology team.

The patient's cardiac valves are as previously described, with consideration given to transesophageal ech

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 53-year-old male with a history of obesity, obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), and depression. The patient presented with increasing shortness of breath (SOB) over the past five days. Initial examination showed bibasilar rales and cool extremities, and a chest X-ray suggested acute congestive heart failure (CHF). Laboratory results indicated lactic acidosis, acute renal failure (ARF), and elevated liver enzymes. An echocardiogram confirmed moderate to severe mitral regurgitation (MR).

The differential diagnosis for the patient's SOB includes acute MR, tachycardia-induced cardiomyopathy, and tamponade. Non-cardiac causes such as infection with compensatory tachypnea or pulmonary embolus were also considered but deemed less likely.

The patient was placed on mechanical ventilation, and various treatments were initiated. These included levophed for inotropy, titrated based on urine output (UOP) and cardiac index (CI), nitroprusside to improve left ventricular forward flow if afterload increased, dobutamine if the heart rate slowed, and consideration of an urgent balloon pump if the patient remained hemodynamically unstable or experienced respiratory compromise.

Further evaluation and management plans include assessing the patient's valves, considering a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE), and evaluating for coronary artery disease if the patient goes to catheterization for a

   Assessment and Plan
   53yo male with history of obesity, OSA, and depression who p/w
   increasing SOB x5d.  Initial exam with bibasilar rales and cool
   extremities with CXR suggestive of acute CHF.  Labs with lactic
   acidosis, ARF, and elevated liver enzymes and echo c/w mod/severe MR.
   DDx of SOB broad but given above findings, cardiogenic shock is likely
   etiology.
   .
   # SOB: as above; likely from cardiogenic shock from ? acute MR.  DDx
   includes acute MR, tachycardia induced cardiomyopathy, tamponade.  Non
   cardiac etiologies include infection with compensatory tachynpea,
   pulmonary embolus (possible given tachynpea, elevated CVP but unlikely
   to cause MR).  Provide supportive resp care and treat as below.
   .
   # Cardiogenic shock: Suspect [**3-20**] MR given acute onset 5d ago and no
   known hx of MR.  Tachycardia likely compensatory to increase CO.  EF is
   depressed globally without regional wall motion abnl so less likely
   ACS.  Acute viral cardiomyopathy unlikely given lack of fevers, B sx.
   Tamponade unlikely given none seen on echo.
   - treat acute MR [**First Name (Titles) 1187**] [**Last Name (Titles) 6145**] tachycardia.  Will try levophed for
   inotropy and will titrate to changes in UOP and CI.  Reassess 1h after
   starting and if no improvement, will consider alternative options.
   - If afterload increases, will try nitroprusside to improve LV forward
   flow.
   - If heart rate slows, will try dobutamine
   - If hemodynamically unstable or resp compromise, will d/w cards team
   for consideration of urgent balloon pump
   .
   # Cards Valves: as above.  Await official read of echo in am.  Consider
   TEE.  If acute MR confirmed, will d/w cards and CT [**Doctor First Name **]
   .
   # Cards Pump: depressed globally.  augment as above
   .
   # Cards vasc: has delayed RWP on EKG but CE negative.
   - ASA 325
   - complete ROMI
   - consider eval of coronaries if goes to cath for balloon
   .
   # Cards rhythm: aflutter.  Will tolerate HR to 130 for increased CO.
   If rises and unstable, will do cardioversion.
   - hold nodal agents
   .
   # Transaminitis: suspect shock liver vs congestion from cardiogenic
   shock.  Trend daily INR, glucose, and ALT/AST.  Will d/w liver c/s team
   .
   # ARF: Suspect prerenal from poor forward flow vs ATN from hypotension.
   - try to augment cardiac output.
   - check renal lytes
   - if worsens, will d/w renal
   .
   # ID: no clear source of infection.  Received ceftriaxone in ED.  Only
   small ascites so no para overnight.  Will culture elsewhere
   - hold abx
   .
   # Anion gap acidosis: likely from lactate production.  Delta/delta -2
   so no non-gap.
   - check ABG and repeat lactate
   .
   # OSA: will do bipap if stable for sleep
   .
   # Psych: will confirm dosages of meds in am and restart then
   .
   # Hyponatremia: suspect [**3-20**] cardiogenic shock.  Total body up but renal
   perfusion low.
   .
   # FEN: NPO for now.  No IVF given CVP up and risks going into lungs
   .
   # ACCESS: CVL.  obtain Aline
   .
   # Proph: SQH, bowel regimen, HISS
   .
   # Pain control: monitor low back pain
   .
   # Code: full
   .
   # Contact; Wife [**Telephone/Fax (1) 6146**] is HCP
   .

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 53-year-old male with a history of obesity, obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), and depression. He presented with increasing shortness of breath (SOB) over five days and was initially found to have bibasilar rales and cool extremities. The chest X-ray suggested acute congestive heart failure (CHF). Lab results indicated lactic acidosis, acute renal failure (ARF), and elevated liver enzymes. An echocardiogram confirmed moderate to severe mitral regurgitation (MR). 

The differential diagnosis for SOB includes acute MR, tachycardia-induced cardiomyopathy, and tamponade. Non-cardiac causes such as infection and pulmonary embolus were also considered but less likely. The patient is currently receiving supportive respiratory care and being treated for cardiogenic shock, suspected due to severe MR. 

The plan includes treating acute MR, tachycardia, and assessing for potential interventions such as levophed for inotropy, nitroprusside for afterload reduction, and dobutamine if the heart rate slows. If the patient remains hemodynamically unstable or experiences respiratory compromise, an urgent balloon pump may be considered. 

Further evaluation of the patient's valves, cardiac pump function, and vascular status is planned. The patient's rhythm is currently atrial flutter, and efforts to control the heart rate are ongoing. Transaminitis, ARF,

   53yo male with history of obesity, OSA, and depression who p/w
   increasing SOB x5d and found to have 3+ MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 4298**] TTE with
   hemodynamics consistent with cardiogenic shock. Now s/p intubation and
   cardioversion x1.
   .
   # Cardiogenic shock: Suspect [**3-20**] MR given acute onset 5d ago and no
   known hx of MR, but given elevated RIGHT sided pressures there is some
   suggestion that this might be a chronic process. Depressed EF may be
   partially due to rhythm disturbance. Patient likely had chronic process
   that was exacerbated by several days of Aflutter that precipitated
   cardiogenic shock. CI improved up to 2.4. Warm extremities reassuring
   that shock is improving on Milrinone, Levophed and Dopamine. Failed
   cardioversion yesterday. LFTs improving but renal function unchanged
   suggesting possible component of ATN. Bordeline high temperatures
   likely reflect improving cardiogenic shock rather than sepsis. Elevated
   PA and PCWP with low pulmonary vascular resistance further support
   cardiogenic shock.
   - Try to d/c Dopamine today
   - Continue Milrinone
   - Lasix gtt for diuresis given fluid overload. Will test bolus with
   Diuril 500 mg IVx1 this am.
   - Monitor Fick Q change of shift and with change in clinical status
   .
   # Atrial Flutter: S/p 2 failed cardioversions. Patient did convert for
   some time yesterday, but did go back into flutter indicating that
   patient will likely require more improvement in volume status prior to
   being able to maintain NSR. Plan to continue amiodarone and try to
   improve volume status with lasix and diuril to help improve RA
   geometry.
   - Continue Amiodarone
   - Continue heparin gtt
   - Plan to use lasix and diuril for goal I/O negative 500 cc to 1L. Will
   minimize IV intake as much as possible.
   - EP consult tomorrow re: possible need for ablation
   .
   # Coronaries: Biomarkers flat. ROMI complete.
   ASA 325
   # Respiratory failure: Intubated [**7-9**] peri-cardioversion. Hypoxic
   likely due to medication (ativan) and pulmonary edema. Since fluid
   status has not been improved will defer extubation for now. Became
   tachypnic with SBT today.
   - Continue PS ventilation 12/5
   .
   # Abdominal distention: KUB unremarkable. NG tube with mild to moderate
   output. [**Month (only) 11**] be functional ileus in setting of sepsis and depressive
   agents.
   - Continue NG to low suction
   .
   # Transaminitis: suspect shock liver. LFTs improving. INR elevated but
   stable.
   .  Trend daily INR, glucose, and ALT/AST.
   .
   # ARF: Suspect ATN in setting of cardiogenic shock as noted above.
   Since Cr has not improved with better hemodynamics, I assume more
   likely ATN
   - try to augment cardiac output.
   - renal dose meds
   - if worsens, will d/w renal
   # Hyponatremia: suspect [**3-20**] cardiogenic shock.  Total body up but renal
   perfusion low.
   .
   # FEN: NPO for now.  No TFs given NG output.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 53-year-old male with a history of obesity, obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), and depression. He presented with increasing shortness of breath over the past five days and was found to have 3+ mitral regurgitation (MR) on echocardiography. The patient underwent intubation and cardioversion.

Assessment and Plan:
The patient is suspected to have cardiogenic shock due to acute onset MR and no known history of MR. The patient's right-sided pressures suggest a chronic process. A depressed ejection fraction may be partially due to rhythm disturbance. The patient likely had a chronic process that was exacerbated by several days of atrial flutter, leading to cardiogenic shock. The cardiac index improved up to 2.4, indicating improving shock status with the use of milrinone, levophed, and dopamine. Failed cardioversion yesterday. Liver function tests are improving, but renal function remains unchanged, suggesting possible acute tubular necrosis (ATN). Borderline high temperatures are likely reflecting improving cardiogenic shock rather than sepsis. Elevated pulmonary artery (PA) and pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) with low pulmonary vascular resistance further support cardiogenic shock.

Plan:
1. Try to discontinue dopamine today.
2. Continue milrinone.
3. Lasix gtt for diuresis given fluid overload. Will test bolus with Diuril 500 mg IVx1 this

   53yo male with history of obesity, OSA, and depression who p/w
   increasing SOB x5d and found to have 3+ MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 4298**] TTE with
   hemodynamics consistent with cardiogenic shock. Now s/p intubation and
   cardioversion x1.
   .
   # Cardiogenic shock:: CI drifting down to 1.9 from 2.4 yesterday likely
   due to reduced tachycardia and elevated MAPs.  Interestingly MAPs
   higher since dopamine stopped yesterday. Elevated PA and PCWP with low
   pulmonary vascular resistance further support cardiogenic shock.
   - Increase Milrinone  to 2.5 to reduce MAPs and impove ionotropy
   - Lasix gtt for diuresis given fluid overload. Will bolus with Diuril
   500 mg IVx1 this am after such good response yesterday.
   - Monitor Fick Q change of shift and with change in clinical status
   - Repeat TTE today
   - Complete Cardiomyopathy work up
   - CHF consult today
   .
   # Atrial Flutter: EKG c/w Sinus tach this am. Appeared to convert after
   dopamine stopped yesterday. Plan to continue amiodarone and try to
   improve volume status with lasix and diuril to help improve RA
   geometry.
   - Continue Amiodarone. Patient 900 mg into load as of 6 pm last night.
   - Continue heparin gtt
   - Plan to use lasix and diuril for goal I/O negative 1 L.
   -  [**Last Name (un) 6202**] EP consult for now
   .
   # Coronaries: Biomarkers flat. ROMI complete.
   - ASA 325
   - Will need cath prior to dispo to eval for ischemic cardiomyopathy
   # Respiratory failure: Intubated [**7-9**] peri-cardioversion. Fluid status
   improved.
   - Continue PS ventilation 12/5 will defer Extubation until tomorrow in
   case of cath today
   .
   # Abdominal distention: KUB unremarkable. NG output more bilious. Hct
   stable.
   - Clamp NG tube
   .
   # Transaminitis: suspect shock liver. LFTs improving. INR elevated but
   stable.
   .  Trend daily INR, glucose, and ALT/AST.
   .
   # ARF: Suspect ATN in setting of cardiogenic shock as noted above.
   Since Cr has not improved with better hemodynamics, I assume more
   likely ATN
   - try to augment cardiac output.
   - renal dose meds

Summary:
The patient is a 53-year-old male with a history of obesity, obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), and depression. He presented with increasing shortness of breath (SOB) for five days and was found to have moderate to severe mitral regurgitation (MR) on transthoracic echocardiography (TTE). The patient's hemodynamics are consistent with cardiogenic shock. He underwent intubation and cardioversion once. The patient's condition has been complicated by atrial flutter, fluid overload, respiratory failure, abdominal distention, transaminitis, acute renal failure (ARF), and fasting state.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient's current condition suggests cardiogenic shock, which is characterized by poor tissue perfusion and hypotension due to impaired cardiac function. This can lead to organ dysfunction and failure if not managed promptly.
2. Atrial Flutter: The patient's EKG shows sinus tachycardia, which may mask atrial flutter. Atrial flutter can lead to irregular heart rhythm and reduce cardiac output, further compromising the patient's hemodynamic status.
3. Fluid Overload: The patient's fluid balance shows a significant negative balance, indicating fluid overload. If not addressed, this can lead to electrolyte imbalances, increased preload, and worsen heart failure symptoms.
4. Respiratory Failure: The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation. If the patient

   8. NG-tube clamped
   # CARDIOGENIC SHOCK. The patient has cardiogenic shock as evidenced by
   low CI and high SVR. [**Last Name (Titles) **] showed LVEF 20-25% (systolic dysfunction) as
   well as restrictive LV filling suggestive of diastolic dysfunction.
   Fick values over the past 24 hours:
   1PM (pre-IABP): CI=1.8; CO=4.3; SVR=1100; SvO2=57; Hb=12.2
   6PM (post-IABP): CI=2.1; CO=4.9; SVR=925; SvO2=61
   10PM: CI=2.5; CO=5.9; SVR=____; SvO2=67
   Increased milrinone to 0.5. IABP placed yesterday, at 1:1 with MAPs in
   80s.
   Urine output has been 150-300cc per hour in last 24 hours.
   CXR looks stable in terms of pulmonary congestion.
   Plan: continue balloon pump 1:1, milrinon at 0.5. HR is controlled in
   80-90s, but if 110s then we can consider BB to better fill
   diastolically. Continue to follow CI and diuresis, goal -2L. While
   providing supportive care, continue to investigate etiology. Sent ESR,
   [**Doctor First Name **], RF, spep/upep, ... could be tachy, could be valvular disease, will

   The potential etiologies of this patient's cardiomyopathy are vast,
   including: ischemic, tachycardia-induced, valvular, infectious
   ([**Location (un) **] [self-limited], HIV, other viral and non-viral), substance
   abuse (alcohol, cocaine), infiltrative (sarcoid, amyloidosis [SPEP,
   UPEP], hemochromatosis), connective tissue disease (high [**Doctor First Name **] titer),
   hypertensive, myocarditis (could check Fas and FasL), medication
   (doxorubicin, ?seroquel). Unfortunately, nearly 50% of the time,
   work-up will turn out idiopathic (see [**Last Name (un) 6252**] et [**Doctor Last Name **], NEJM [**2115**]). He is
   probably too unstable for endomyocardial biopsy. Will investigate these
   etiologies as appropriate.

   non-invasive study, abd US to r/o aortic dissection, liver consult.

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 53-year-old male with a history of obesity, obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), and depression. He presented with increasing shortness of breath for five days and was found to have biventricular systolic dysfunction, restrictive left ventricular dysfunction, and moderate to severe mitral regurgitation. The patient's hemodynamics are consistent with cardiogenic shock. He has undergone intubation, cardioversion, cardiac catheterization (clean coronaries), and intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP) placement.

The patient's current medical conditions include:

1. Shock: The patient has cardiogenic shock as evidenced by low cardiac index (CI) and high systemic vascular resistance (SVR).
2. Rhythm: The patient is in sinus rhythm now, on amiodarone. He did not undergo cardioversion in the lab today.
3. Coronaries: Clean coronaries were found during cardiac catheterization.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient was intubated for airway protection due to respiratory failure. He is currently on assist-control ventilation mode.
5. Acute renal failure (ARF): Suspected acute tubular necrosis (ATN) in the setting of cardiogenic shock. Renal dose medications are being given.
6. Transaminitis: Suspected shock liver. Liver function tests (LFTs) are improving, but the patient has an elevated INR.

   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN
   53yo male with history of obesity, OSA, and depression who p/w
   increasing SOB x5d, found to have biventricular systolic dysfunction,
   restrictive LV dysfunction, 3+ MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) **] with hemodynamics consistent
   with cardiogenic shock. Now s/p intubation, cardioversion, cardiac cath
   (clean coronaries), IABP placement.
   # CARDIOGENIC SHOCK.
        The patient has been in cardiogenic shock as evidenced by
   requiring milrinone at 0.5 and IABP at 1:1 to maintain CI in the
   2.1-2.5 range and SvO2 in low 60s (goal CI>2.5, SvO2>70). MAPs have
   been stable in the 80s (goal >65) and [**Last Name (Titles) **] showed LVEF 20-25%. His
   CI/SvO2 are improving, but we will need to see more improvement if we
   are to wean his IABP. He has had great urine output (150-300cc per
   hour) on diuril bolus x1 and lasix gtt. CXR looks stable in terms of
   pulmonary congestion. We will plan to continue milrinone at 0.5 and
   IABP at 1:1 with goal CI>2.5. Goal I/O will be even because he likely
   has contraction alkalosis, so we will d/c lasix gtt if UOP remains
   high.
        While providing supportive care, we continue to investigate
   etiology. The potential etiologies of this patient's cardiomyopathy are
   vast, including: ischemic, valvular, tachycardia-induced, infectious
   ([**Location (un) **] [self-limited], HIV, and others), substance abuse (alcohol,
   cocaine), infiltrative (sarcoid, amyloidosis [SPEP, UPEP],
   hemochromatosis), connective tissue disease (high [**Doctor First Name **] titer),
   hypertensive, myocarditis (could check Fas and FasL), medication
   (doxorubicin). Unfortunately, nearly 50% of the time, work-up will turn
   out idiopathic (see [**Last Name (un) 6252**] et [**Doctor Last Name **], NEJM [**2115**]).
        Cardiomyopathy workup to date makes valvular and ischemic
   etiologies unlikely causes of his cardiomyopathy:
   - Transthoracic echocardiogram showed 3+ mitral regurgitation, which
   raised the possibility that his cardiomyopathy is secondary to mitral
   valve disease. However, further examination revealed that the mitral
   valve annulus is increased in diameter, which suggests that mitral
   regurgitation developed secondary to the dilated ventricle.
   Furthermore, his PCWP on admission was 48, which is too high suggest
   acute MR.
   - Regional hypokinesis on [**Year (4 digits) **] suggested that the patient may have
   ischemic disease resulting in regional infarction of cardiac tissue.
   However, cardiac catheterization revealed clean coronaries, making
   ischemic etiology very unlikely.
        Although an infiltrative process is less likely because he does
   not have a restrictive pattern of cardiac disease, we are still
   investigating this possibility because the causes could be reversible.
   These include: ESR/[**Doctor First Name **] to investigate for sarcoidosis and SLE and giant
   cell arteritis, SPEP/UPEP for amyloidosis (although these could still
   be negative if amyloidosis is primarily cardiac), RF for rheumatoid
   cardiac disease, and iron studies for hemochromatosis.
        For transplant work-up, will need Hep B/C, CMV, HIV, carotid
   non-invasive study, abd US to r/o aortic dissection, liver evaluation.
   Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **] will facilitate.
   -          Cont milrinone 0.5 and IABP 1:1
   -          d/c lasix gtt
   -          I/O goal even
   -          f/u labs to investigate etiology
   -          consent wife for HIV testing
   -          f/u SPEP/UPEP
   .
   # RHYTHM.
        He is in sinus rhythm now, on amiodarone load with goal to get to
   10g. His rate was in 80s but now is high in 120s. Once he is amio
   loaded, 200mg PO bid.
   -          Cont amiodarone
   -          Repeat EKG in PM
   .
   # CORONARIES.
        Clean per cath.
   .
   # ACID-BASE IMBALANCE.
        A contraction alkalosis occurs when there is loss of relatively
   large volumes of bicarbonate-free fluid, and IV loop diuretics which
   induce large fluid diuresis commonly cause contraction alkalosis (see
   [**Doctor Last Name 6257**] et [**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) **] Intern Med [**2080**], and [**Doctor First Name 1885**] et [**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) **] [**2092**]).
   Because our patient diuresed over 3L yesterday and even more the days
   before, contraction metabolic alkalosis [**3-20**] lasix/diuril is the most
   likely explanation for his high HCO3. However, the patient
s ABG
   revealed a high PaCO2 of 60 this morning, which suggests there is a
   compensatory respiratory acidosis. In addition, there must be at least
   some component of a primary respiratory acidosis because his pH was
   7.35 this AM. Still, his vent settings will need to have a low rate and
   maintain that respiratory acidosis because it is mostly compensatory.
   Giving IVF at this time would be counter-productive given his clinical
   picture, but giving K+ would help correct his acid-base imbalance
   because he would waste less H+ in his urine.
   -          Replete K+ prn
   -          f/u lytes in PM
   -          Goal: even i/o
    .
   # RESPIRATORY FAILURE.
        The patient is on a ventilator on assist control. Rate was
   increased to 20 this AM and
improved
 his acid-base status. However,
   because he needs respiratory acidosis to correct for metabolic
   alkalosis, we will bring his rate down to 16.
   -          Continue rate 16 with assist control
   -          Consider switching to PS tomorrow if acid-base is balanced
   -          f/u ABG at 2PM
   .
   # FEVER.
        The patient had a mild fever to 100.2 today. We will pan-culture
   to look for etiologies.
   - f/u UA, Ucx, Bcx, Sputum Cx
   .
   # TRANSAMINITIS: suspect shock liver. LFTs improving. INR elevated but
   stable.
   -          Trend daily INR, glucose, and ALT/AST.
   .
   # ARF: Suspect ATN in setting of cardiogenic shock as noted above. Cr
   is slightly improving.
   - Trend Cr
   - I/O goal even today.
   - renal dose meds
   .
   # FEN: Tube feeds can be restarted today because the patient no longer
   has NG tube output.
   - Restart TFs
   .
   # ACCESS: Cordis with Swan and IJ access. A line. Peripherals
   .
   # Proph: Hep gtt, bowel regimen, HISS
   .
   # Pain control: appears comfortable
   .
   # Code: full
   .
   # Contact; Wife [**Telephone/Fax (1) 6146**] is HCP
   .
   # Dispo: CCU

Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient is a 53-year-old male with a history of obesity, obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), and depression. He presented with increasing shortness of breath (SOB) for five days and was found to have biventricular systolic dysfunction, restrictive left ventricular dysfunction, and moderate global right ventricular hypokinesis. The patient is currently in cardiogenic shock and has been intubated, cardioverted, and placed on intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP) support.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.9C (100.2F), heart rate in the range of 113-121 beats per minute (bpm), blood pressure ranging from 97/76 to 116/80 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation of 96%, and sinus tachycardia.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, slightly decreased hemoglobin, elevated creatinine, and abnormal liver function tests (LFTs). The arterial blood gas (ABG) reveals a pH of 7.35, elevated pCO2, normal pO2, and increased HCO3-.

Summary:
The patient is a 53-year-old male with a history of obesity, obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), and depression. He presented with increasing shortness of breath and was found to have biventricular systolic dysfunction, restrictive left ventricular dysfunction, and moderate mitral regurgitation. The patient is currently in cardiogenic shock with low cardiac index (CI) and high systemic vascular resistance (SVR). He has been intubated for airway protection and is on mechanical ventilation. The patient also has respiratory failure, acute kidney injury (AKI), and elevated pulmonary artery pressures.

Medical Complications:
1. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient's low CI and high SVR indicate cardiogenic shock. This is further supported by elevated pulmonary artery pressures (PAP) and pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP).
2. Tachyarrhythmia: The patient initially had atrial flutter, which converted into sinus tachycardia. He is currently on amiodarone to maintain sinus rhythm.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient required intubation due to airway protection during cardioversion and subsequent respiratory failure. He is currently on assist-control ventilation with plans for weaning.
4. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient has AKI, likely due to cardiogenic shock. His renal function needs to be monitored closely.

   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN
   53yo male with history of obesity, OSA, and depression who p/w
   increasing SOB x5d, found to have biventricular systolic dysfunction,
   restrictive LV dysfunction, 3+ MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) **] with hemodynamics consistent
   with cardiogenic shock. Now s/p intubation, cardioversion, cardiac cath
   (clean coronaries), IABP placement.
   1. shock
   2. rhythm. flutter resolved with amio and diuresis. loaded up amio 300
   in the cath lab, cont on amio drip, appears in sinus. Goal HR 80-90 to
   augment filling pressures. ?start BB.
   3. coronaries - clean
   4. respiratory failure. intubated for airway protection. to extubate,
   goal diuresed and MS stable. He needs to be still for the balloon pump,
   so keep on fentanyl/versed.
   5. ARF.
   6. Pre-transplant evaluation.
   7. Trans-aminitis
   8. NG-tube clamped
   # CARDIOGENIC SHOCK. The patient has cardiogenic shock as evidenced by
   low CI and high SVR. [**Last Name (Titles) **] showed LVEF 20-25% (systolic dysfunction) as
   well as restrictive LV filling suggestive of diastolic dysfunction.
   Fick values over the past 24 hours:
   1PM (pre-IABP): CI=1.8; CO=4.3; SVR=1100; SvO2=57; Hb=12.2
   6PM (post-IABP): CI=2.1; CO=4.9; SVR=925; SvO2=61
   10PM: CI=2.5; CO=5.9; SVR=____; SvO2=67
   Increased milrinone to 0.5. IABP placed yesterday, at 1:1 with MAPs in
   80s.
   Urine output has been 150-300cc per hour in last 24 hours.
   CXR looks stable in terms of pulmonary congestion.
   Plan: continue balloon pump 1:1, milrinon at 0.5. HR is controlled in
   80-90s, but if 110s then we can consider BB to better fill
   diastolically. Continue to follow CI and diuresis, goal -2L. While
   providing supportive care, continue to investigate etiology. Sent ESR,
   [**Doctor First Name **], RF, spep/upep, ... could be tachy, could be valvular disease, will
   discuss with Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **] about cardiac transplant, will call liver team
   pre-transplant.
   Cardiomyopathy workup to date includes [**First Name (STitle) **] (MR 3+), cath (clean
   coronaries), ESR, [**Doctor First Name **], RF, spep/upep, iron studies.
   The potential etiologies of this patient's cardiomyopathy are vast,
   including: ischemic, tachycardia-induced, valvular, infectious
   ([**Location (un) **] [self-limited], HIV, other viral and non-viral), substance
   abuse (alcohol, cocaine), infiltrative (sarcoid, amyloidosis [SPEP,
   UPEP], hemochromatosis), connective tissue disease (high [**Doctor First Name **] titer),
   hypertensive, myocarditis (could check Fas and FasL), medication
   (doxorubicin, ?seroquel). Unfortunately, nearly 50% of the time,
   work-up will turn out idiopathic (see [**Last Name (un) 6252**] et [**Doctor Last Name **], NEJM [**2115**]). He is
   probably too unstable for endomyocardial biopsy. Will investigate these
   etiologies as appropriate.
   For transplant work-up, will need Hep B/C, CMV, HIV, carotid
   non-invasive study, abd US to r/o aortic dissection, liver consult.
   His MR is likely chronic, not acute, because his PCWP was 48 (which is
   more elevated than expected in a healthy person with acute MR).
   ## RHYTHM: He is in sinus rhythm now, on amiodarone. He did not get
   cardioverted in the lab today
   He is on lasix 15
   Amiodarone to keep him in sinus rhythm. Will complete load of 10g, then
   we can taper down... Calculate how much he got it (as of 6PM he got
   900mg, when he wakes up he can get high dose PO). Then 200mg PO bid
   when he wakes up and the loading is done.
   In the cath lab, he had carotid massage which slowed his HR. His
   responsiveness to this vasovagal maneuver indicates his tachyarrhythmia
   was less likely a-flutter. His increased HR was more likely physiologic
   response to cardiogenic shock,
   His a-flutter from the day before seemed to convert into a
   tachyarrhythmia after the dopamine was weaned off, which makes sense
   because dopamine has beta-adrenergic effect.
   His HR is better now because of the balloon pump. His tachyacardia was
   physiology ic because of the shock. Now wit hthe balloon the
   hemodynamics are better, so his HR is lower.
   # RESPIRATORY FAILURE
   [**Name6 (MD) 1030**] the RN was switching from propofol to fentanyl/versed, the
   patient became apneic. He was placed on assist control. *If overnight
   he overbreathes the vent settings, then we can switch him to PS in the
   morning. If he does not overbreath the vent, then we can wean sedation
   in the morning around rounds time, and wean the AC to minimal settings,
   and give him a "breathing trial." If he has spontaenous breaths, we can
   place him on PS again.
   NOTE:
   You can catually terminate v-tach with carotid massage.
   # ELEVATED PAP
   - it is contraindication to heart transplant if it is primary.
   - The etiology is still in the works. If it is due to CHF, we would
   expect these values to get better as he is now on increased milrinone
   and on the balloon pump.
   - h/o OSA, which could be etiology
   .
   # Cardiogenic shock:: CI drifting down to 1.9 from 2.4 yesterday likely
   due to reduced tachycardia and elevated MAPs.  Interestingly MAPs
   higher since dopamine stopped yesterday. Elevated PA and PCWP with low
   pulmonary vascular resistance further support cardiogenic shock.
   - Increase Milrinone  to 2.5 to reduce MAPs and impove ionotropy
   - Lasix gtt for diuresis given fluid overload. Will bolus with Diuril
   500 mg IVx1 this am after such good response yesterday.
   - Monitor Fick Q change of shift and with change in clinical status
   - Repeat [**Name6 (MD) **] today
   - Complete Cardiomyopathy work up
   - CHF consult today
   .
   # Atrial Flutter: EKG c/w Sinus tach this am. Appeared to convert after
   dopamine stopped yesterday. Plan to continue amiodarone and try to
   improve volume status with lasix and diuril to help improve RA
   geometry.
   - Continue Amiodarone. Patient 900 mg into load as of 6 pm last night.
   - Continue heparin gtt
   - Plan to use lasix and diuril for goal I/O negative 1 L.
   -  [**Last Name (un) 6202**] EP consult for now
   .
   # Coronaries: Biomarkers flat. ROMI complete.
   - ASA 325
   - Will need cath prior to dispo to eval for ischemic cardiomyopathy
   # Respiratory failure: Intubated [**7-9**] peri-cardioversion. Fluid status
   improved.
   - Continue PS ventilation 12/5 will defer Extubation until tomorrow in
   case of cath today
   .
   # Abdominal distention: KUB unremarkable. NG output more bilious. Hct
   stable.
   - Clamp NG tube
   .
   # Transaminitis: suspect shock liver. LFTs improving. INR elevated but
   stable.
   .  Trend daily INR, glucose, and ALT/AST.
   .
   # ARF: Suspect ATN in setting of cardiogenic shock as noted above.
   Since Cr has not improved with better hemodynamics, I assume more
   likely ATN
   - try to augment cardiac output.
   - renal dose meds
   - if worsens, will d/w renal
   # FEN: NPO for now.  No TFs given NG output. Will trial TFs if clamped
   NG tube successful.
   .
   # ACCESS: Cordis with Swan and IJ access. A line. Peripherals
   .
   # Proph: Hep gtt, bowel regimen, HISS
   .
   # Pain control: appears comfortable
   .
   # Code: full
   .
   # Contact; Wife [**Telephone/Fax (1) 6146**] is HCP
   .
   # Dispo: CCU
   Patient remains Hemodynamically unstable with dependence on IABP and
   milrinone.  Respiratory status compromised by volume overload and
   metabolic alkalosis.  Hold diuretics for now.  Monitor I/O and
   acid/base status.  Follow creatinine.  Transplant work-up in parallel
   should be become IABP and pressor dependent

Summary:
Based on the provided information, there are several potential medical complications that can arise for this patient:

1. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient has been diagnosed with cardiogenic shock due to severe systolic and diastolic dysfunction of the left ventricle. This condition requires immediate medical intervention to stabilize the patient's hemodynamics and improve cardiac output.

2. Respiratory Failure: The patient has been intubated due to respiratory failure, which may be a result of fluid overload, metabolic alkalosis, or underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary syndrome (OSA). Close monitoring of the patient's respiratory status is necessary to assess the effectiveness of ventilatory support and consider extubation once stable.

3. Renal Failure: The patient's renal function is impaired, as indicated by elevated creatinine levels. This could be due to acute tubular necrosis (ATN) or cardiorenal syndrome. Ongoing monitoring of renal function and appropriate management to support kidney function are essential.

4. Abdominal Distention: The patient presents with abdominal distention, which may be caused by bowel obstruction or ileus. Further evaluation, such as an abdominal ultrasound or CT scan, can help identify the underlying cause. If necessary, appropriate interventions can be implemented to relieve the distention.

5. Transaminitis: The patient has elevated liver enzymes, suggestive of transaminitis. This could be a result of shock liver or other underlying liver pathology. Monitoring of liver function tests and appropriate management based

   we can taper down... Calculate how much he got it (as of 6PM he got
   900mg, when he wakes up he can get high dose PO). Then 200mg PO bid
   when he wakes up and the loading is done.
   In the cath lab, he had carotid massage which slowed his HR. His
   responsiveness to this vasovagal maneuver indicates his tachyarrhythmia
   was less likely a-flutter. His increased HR was more likely physiologic
   response to cardiogenic shock,
   His a-flutter from the day before seemed to convert into a
   tachyarrhythmia after the dopamine was weaned off, which makes sense
   because dopamine has beta-adrenergic effect.
   His HR is better now because of the balloon pump. His tachyacardia was
   physiology ic because of the shock. Now wit hthe balloon the

   dopamine stopped yesterday. Plan to continue amiodarone and try to
   improve volume status with lasix and diuril to help improve RA

2. Respiratory failure: The patient has been intubated due to respiratory failure, which occurred during the transition from propofol to fentanyl/versed. Extubation will depend on the patient's ability to maintain adequate ventilation and oxygenation.

3. Acute kidney injury (ATN): The patient's elevated creatinine levels suggest the possibility of acute tubular necrosis (ATN).    ASSESSMENT AND PLAN
   53yo male with history of obesity, OSA, and depression who p/w
   increasing SOB x5d, found to have biventricular systolic dysfunction,
   restrictive LV dysfunction, 3+ MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) **] with hemodynamics consistent

   (clean coronaries), IABP placement.
   # CARDIOGENIC SHOCK.
        The patient has been in cardiogenic shock as evidenced by
   requiring milrinone at 0.5 and IABP at 1:1 to maintain CI in the
   2.1-2.5 range and SvO2 in low 60s (goal CI>2.5, SvO2>70). MAPs have
   been stable in the 80s (goal >65) and [**Last Name (Titles) **] showed LVEF 20-25%. His
   CI/SvO2 are improving, but we will need to see more improvement if we
   are to wean his IABP. He has had great urine output (150-300cc per
   hour) on diuril bolus x1 and lasix gtt. CXR looks stable in terms of
   pulmonary congestion. We will plan to continue milrinone at 0.5 and
   IABP at 1:1 with goal CI>2.5. Goal I/O will be even because he likely
   has contraction alkalosis, so we will d/c lasix gtt if UOP remains
   high.
        While providing supportive care, we continue to investigate
   etiology. The potential etiologies of this patient's cardiomyopathy are
   vast, including: ischemic, valvular, tachycardia-induced, infectious
   ([**Location (un) **] [self-limited], HIV, and others), substance abuse (alcohol,
   cocaine), infiltrative (sarcoid, amyloidosis [SPEP, UPEP],
   hemochromatosis), connective tissue disease (high [**Doctor First Name **] titer),

        Cardiomyopathy workup to date makes valvular and ischemic
   etiologies unlikely causes of his cardiomyopathy:
   - Transthoracic echocardiogram showed 3+ mitral regurgitation, which
   raised the possibility that his cardiomyopathy is secondary to mitral
   valve disease. However, further examination revealed that the mitral
   valve annulus is increased in diameter, which suggests that mitral
   regurgitation developed secondary to the dilated ventricle.
   Furthermore, his PCWP on admission was 48, which is too high suggest
   acute MR.
   - Regional hypokinesis on [**Year (4 digits) **] suggested that the patient may have
   ischemic disease resulting in regional infarction of cardiac tissue.
   However, cardiac catheterization revealed clean coronaries, making
   ischemic etiology very unlikely.
        Although an infiltrative process is less likely because he does
   not have a restrictive pattern of cardiac disease, we are still
   investigating this possibility because the causes could be reversible.
   These include: ESR/[**Doctor First Name **] to investigate for sarcoidosis and SLE and giant
   cell arteritis, SPEP/UPEP for amyloidosis (although these could still

   cardiac disease, and iron studies for hemochromatosis.

Summary:
The patient is a 53-year-old male with a history of obesity, obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), and depression who presented with increasing shortness of breath over the past five days. He was found to have biventricular systolic dysfunction, restrictive left ventricular dysfunction, and moderate global free wall hypokinesis. The patient's hemodynamics are consistent with cardiogenic shock, and he required intubation, cardioversion, cardiac catheterization (clean coronaries), and intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP) placement.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.2C (99F), heart rate of 113 beats per minute, blood pressure of 97/76 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. He is intubated and on assist control ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL, respiratory rate set at 14, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.

Laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 13.9 x 109/L, hemoglobin of 12.2 g/dL, platelet count of 282 x 109/L, creatinine of 2.4 mg/dL, blood glucose of 120 mg/dL, lactate level of 1.6 mmol/L, and a pH of 7.35. The patient has metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory acidosis, likely due to contraction alkalosis secondary to aggressive diuresis.

The patient has several potential medical complications that can arise. These include:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient is already in cardiogenic shock, as evidenced by his dependence on IABP and milrinone to maintain cardiac index (CI) in the 2.1-2.5 range and mixed venous oxygen saturation (SvO2) in the low 60s. It will be necessary to continue milrinone and IABP support and monitor for further improvement in CI and SvO2.

2. Respiratory failure: The patient is currently intubated and on assist control ventilation due to respiratory failure. His respiratory status is compromised by volume overload and metabolic alkalosis. It will be important to monitor his I/O status and correct any fluid imbalances. Weaning off the ventilator may be considered once his respiratory function improves and his volume status is optimized.

3. Acute kidney injury (ARF): The patient's serum creatinine has been elevated, and he may have acute tubular necrosis (ATN) in the setting of cardiogenic shock. Monitoring his renal function and providing appropriate supportive care, including renal-dose medications, will be important.

4. Transaminitis: The patient has elevated liver enzymes, which may indicate transaminitis. This could be secondary

   Assessment and Plan
   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN
   53yo male with history of obesity, OSA, and depression who p/w
   increasing SOB x5d, found to have biventricular systolic dysfunction,
   restrictive LV dysfunction, 3+ MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) **] with hemodynamics consistent
   with cardiogenic shock. Now s/p intubation, cardioversion, cardiac cath
   (clean coronaries), IABP placement.
   # CARDIOGENIC SHOCK.
        The patient has been in cardiogenic shock as evidenced by
   requiring milrinone at 0.5 and IABP at 1:1 to maintain CI in the
   2.1-2.5 range and SvO2 in low 60s (goal CI>2.5, SvO2>70). MAPs have
   been stable in the 80s (goal >65) and [**Last Name (Titles) **] showed LVEF 20-25%. His
   CI/SvO2 are improving, but we will need to see more improvement if we
   are to wean his IABP. He has had great urine output (150-300cc per
   hour) on diuril bolus x1 and lasix gtt. CXR looks stable in terms of
   pulmonary congestion. We will plan to continue milrinone at 0.5 and
   IABP at 1:1 with goal CI>2.5. Goal I/O will be even because he likely
   has contraction alkalosis, so we will d/c lasix gtt if UOP remains
   high.
        While providing supportive care, we continue to investigate
   etiology. The potential etiologies of this patient's cardiomyopathy are
   vast, including: ischemic, valvular, tachycardia-induced, infectious
   ([**Location (un) **] [self-limited], HIV, and others), substance abuse (alcohol,
   cocaine), infiltrative (sarcoid, amyloidosis [SPEP, UPEP],
   hemochromatosis), connective tissue disease (high [**Doctor First Name **] titer),
   hypertensive, myocarditis (could check Fas and FasL), medication
   (doxorubicin). Unfortunately, nearly 50% of the time, work-up will turn
   out idiopathic (see [**Last Name (un) 6252**] et [**Doctor Last Name **], NEJM [**2115**]).
        Cardiomyopathy workup to date makes valvular and ischemic
   etiologies unlikely causes of his cardiomyopathy:
   - Transthoracic echocardiogram showed 3+ mitral regurgitation, which
   raised the possibility that his cardiomyopathy is secondary to mitral
   valve disease. However, further examination revealed that the mitral
   valve annulus is increased in diameter, which suggests that mitral
   regurgitation developed secondary to the dilated ventricle.
   Furthermore, his PCWP on admission was 48, which is too high suggest
   acute MR.
   - Regional hypokinesis on [**Year (4 digits) **] suggested that the patient may have
   ischemic disease resulting in regional infarction of cardiac tissue.
   However, cardiac catheterization revealed clean coronaries, making
   ischemic etiology very unlikely.
        Although an infiltrative process is less likely because he does
   not have a restrictive pattern of cardiac disease, we are still
   investigating this possibility because the causes could be reversible.
   These include: ESR/[**Doctor First Name **] to investigate for sarcoidosis and SLE and giant
   cell arteritis, SPEP/UPEP for amyloidosis (although these could still
   be negative if amyloidosis is primarily cardiac), RF for rheumatoid
   cardiac disease, and iron studies for hemochromatosis.
        For transplant work-up, will need Hep B/C, CMV, HIV, carotid
   non-invasive study, abd US to r/o aortic dissection, liver evaluation.
   Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **] will facilitate.
   -          Cont milrinone 0.5 and IABP 1:1
   -          d/c lasix gtt
   -          I/O goal even
   -          f/u labs to investigate etiology
   -          consent wife for HIV testing
   -          f/u SPEP/UPEP
   .
   # RHYTHM.
        He is in sinus rhythm now, on amiodarone load with goal to get to
   10g. His rate was in 80s but now is high in 120s. Once he is amio
   loaded, 200mg PO bid.
   -          Cont amiodarone
   -          Repeat EKG in PM
   .
   # CORONARIES.
        Clean per cath.
   .
   # ACID-BASE IMBALANCE.
        The patient has metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory
   acidosis based on high HCO3 and high PaCO2. This is most likely
   contraction alkalosis secondary to aggressive diuresis. Giving IVF at
   this time would be counter-productive given his clinical picture, but
   giving K+ would help correct his acid-base imbalance because he would
   waste less H+ in his urine.
   -          Replete K+ prn
   -          f/u lytes in PM
   -          Goal: even i/o
    .
   # RESPIRATORY FAILURE.
        The patient is on a ventilator on assist control. Rate was
   increased to 20 this AM and
improved
 his acid-base status. However,
   because he needs respiratory acidosis to correct for metabolic
   alkalosis, we will bring his rate down to 16.
   -          Continue rate 16 with assist control
   -          Consider switching to PS tomorrow if acid-base is balanced
   -          f/u ABG at 2PM
   .
   # FEVER.
        The patient had a mild fever to 100.2 today. We will pan-culture
   to look for etiologies.
   - f/u UA, Ucx, Bcx, Sputum Cx
   .
   # TRANSAMINITIS: suspect shock liver. LFTs improving. INR elevated but
   stable.
   -          Trend daily INR, glucose, and ALT/AST.
   .
   # ARF: Suspect ATN in setting of cardiogenic shock as noted above. Cr
   is slightly improving.
   - Trend Cr
   - I/O goal even today.
   - renal dose meds
   .
   # FEN: Tube feeds can be restarted today because the patient no longer
   has NG tube output.
   - Restart TFs
   .
   # ACCESS: Cordis with Swan and IJ access. A line. Peripherals
   .
   # Proph: Hep gtt, bowel regimen, HISS
   .
   # Pain control: appears comfortable
   .
   # Code: full
   .
   # Contact; Wife [**Telephone/Fax (1) 6146**] is HCP
   .
   # Dispo: CCU
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: tube feeds
   Glycemic Control:  ISS

He presented with increasing shortness of breath over five days and was found to have biventricular systolic dysfunction, restrictive left ventricular dysfunction, and moderate global right ventricular hypokinesis. The patient's hemodynamics are consistent with cardiogenic shock, and he has been intubated, cardioverted, and undergone cardiac catheterization (clean coronaries), with an intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP) placed.

CI/SvO2 are improving, but we will need to see more improvement if we are to wean his IABP.

   Assessment and Plan
   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN
   53yo male with history of obesity, OSA, and depression who p/w
   increasing SOB x5d, found to have biventricular systolic dysfunction,
   restrictive LV dysfunction, 3+ MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) **] with hemodynamics consistent
   with cardiogenic shock. Now s/p intubation, cardioversion, cardiac cath
   (clean coronaries), IABP placement.
   # CARDIOGENIC SHOCK.
        The patient has been in cardiogenic shock as evidenced by
   requiring milrinone at 0.5 and IABP at 1:1 to maintain CI in the
   2.1-2.5 range and SvO2 in low 60s (goal CI>2.5, SvO2>70). MAPs have
   been stable in the 80s (goal >65) and [**Last Name (Titles) **] showed LVEF 20-25%. His
   CI/SvO2 are improving, but we will need to see more improvement if we
   are to wean his IABP. He has had great urine output (150-300cc per
   hour) on diuril bolus x1 and lasix gtt. CXR looks stable in terms of
   pulmonary congestion. We will plan to continue milrinone at 0.5 and
   IABP at 1:1 with goal CI>2.5. Goal I/O will be even because he likely
   has contraction alkalosis, so we will d/c lasix gtt if UOP remains
   high.
        While providing supportive care, we continue to investigate
   etiology. The potential etiologies of this patient's cardiomyopathy are
   vast, including: ischemic, valvular, tachycardia-induced, infectious
   ([**Location (un) **] [self-limited], HIV, and others), substance abuse (alcohol,
   cocaine), infiltrative (sarcoid, amyloidosis [SPEP, UPEP],
   hemochromatosis), connective tissue disease (high [**Doctor First Name **] titer),
   hypertensive, myocarditis (could check Fas and FasL), medication
   (doxorubicin). Unfortunately, nearly 50% of the time, work-up will turn
   out idiopathic (see [**Last Name (un) 6252**] et [**Doctor Last Name **], NEJM [**2115**]).
        Cardiomyopathy workup to date makes valvular and ischemic
   etiologies unlikely causes of his cardiomyopathy:
   - Transthoracic echocardiogram showed 3+ mitral regurgitation, which
   raised the possibility that his cardiomyopathy is secondary to mitral
   valve disease. However, further examination revealed that the mitral
   valve annulus is increased in diameter, which suggests that mitral
   regurgitation developed secondary to the dilated ventricle.
   Furthermore, his PCWP on admission was 48, which is too high suggest
   acute MR.
   - Regional hypokinesis on [**Year (4 digits) **] suggested that the patient may have
   ischemic disease resulting in regional infarction of cardiac tissue.
   However, cardiac catheterization revealed clean coronaries, making
   ischemic etiology very unlikely.
        Although an infiltrative process is less likely because he does
   not have a restrictive pattern of cardiac disease, we are still
   investigating this possibility because the causes could be reversible.
   These include: ESR/[**Doctor First Name **] to investigate for sarcoidosis and SLE and giant
   cell arteritis, SPEP/UPEP for amyloidosis (although these could still
   be negative if amyloidosis is primarily cardiac), RF for rheumatoid
   cardiac disease, and iron studies for hemochromatosis.
        For transplant work-up, will need Hep B/C, CMV, HIV, carotid
   non-invasive study, abd US to r/o aortic dissection, liver evaluation.
   Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **] will facilitate.
   -          Cont milrinone 0.5 and IABP 1:1
   -          d/c lasix gtt
   -          I/O goal even
   -          f/u labs to investigate etiology
   -          consent wife for HIV testing
   -          f/u SPEP/UPEP
   .
   # RHYTHM.
        He is in sinus rhythm now, on amiodarone load with goal to get to
   10g. His rate was in 80s but now is high in 120s. Once he is amio
   loaded, 200mg PO bid.
   -          Cont amiodarone
   -          Repeat EKG in PM
   .
   # CORONARIES.
        Clean per cath.
   .
   # ACID-BASE IMBALANCE.
        A contraction alkalosis occurs when there is loss of relatively
   large volumes of bicarbonate-free fluid, and IV loop diuretics which
   induce large fluid diuresis commonly cause contraction alkalosis (see
   [**Doctor Last Name 6257**] et [**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) **] Intern Med [**2080**], and [**Doctor First Name 1885**] et [**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) **] [**2092**]).
   Because our patient diuresed over 3L yesterday and even more the days
   before, contraction metabolic alkalosis [**3-20**] lasix/diuril is the most
   likely explanation for his high HCO3. However, the patient
s ABG
   revealed a high PaCO2 of 60 this morning and a pH of 7.35, which
   suggests there is a compensatory respiratory acidosis. This indicates
   that his vent settings will need to have a low rate in order to
   maintain that respiratory acidosis. Giving IVF at this time would be
   counter-productive given his clinical picture, but giving K+ would help
   correct his acid-base imbalance because he would waste less H+ in his
   urine.
   -          Replete K+ prn
   -          f/u lytes in PM
   -          Goal: even i/o
    .
   # RESPIRATORY FAILURE.
        The patient is on a ventilator on assist control. Rate was
   increased to 20 this AM and
improved
 his acid-base status. However,
   because he needs respiratory acidosis to correct for metabolic
   alkalosis, we will bring his rate down to 16.
   -          Continue rate 16 with assist control
   -          Consider switching to PS tomorrow if acid-base is balanced
   -          f/u ABG at 2PM
   .
   # FEVER.
        The patient had a mild fever to 100.2 today. We will pan-culture
   to look for etiologies.
   - f/u UA, Ucx, Bcx, Sputum Cx
   .
   # TRANSAMINITIS: suspect shock liver. LFTs improving. INR elevated but
   stable.
   -          Trend daily INR, glucose, and ALT/AST.
   .
   # ARF: Suspect ATN in setting of cardiogenic shock as noted above. Cr
   is slightly improving.
   - Trend Cr
   - I/O goal even today.
   - renal dose meds
   .
   # FEN: Tube feeds can be restarted today because the patient no longer
   has NG tube output.
   - Restart TFs
   .
   # ACCESS: Cordis with Swan and IJ access. A line. Peripherals
   .
   # Proph: Hep gtt, bowel regimen, HISS
   .
   # Pain control: appears comfortable
   .
   # Code: full
   .
   # Contact; Wife [**Telephone/Fax (1) 6146**] is HCP
   .
   # Dispo: CCU
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: tube feeds
   Glycemic Control:  ISS

Summary:
The patient is a 53-year-old male with a history of obesity, obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), and depression. He presented with increasing shortness of breath for five days and was found to have biventricular systolic dysfunction, restrictive left ventricular filling pattern suggestive of severe diastolic dysfunction, and moderate global right ventricular free wall hypokinesis. The patient is currently in cardiogenic shock and has been intubated, cardioverted, and placed on intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP) support. His left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) is 20-25%. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient is currently in cardiogenic shock, as evidenced by the need for milrinone and IABP to maintain cardiac index (CI) in the 2.1-2.5 range and mixed venous saturation (SvO2) in the low 60s. Close monitoring and management of hemodynamics are essential to prevent further deterioration.

2. Acid-Base Imbalance: The patient has a high bicarbonate level (HCO3) indicating metabolic alkalosis, likely due to diuresis with lasix/diuril. There is also a compensatory respiratory acidosis with a high PaCO2 of 60. Careful attention to ventilator settings and electrolyte management is required to maintain acid-base balance.

   higher since dopamine stopped yesterday. Elevated PA and PCWP with low
   pulmonary vascular resistance further support cardiogenic shock.

The patient is a 53-year-old male with a history of obesity, obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), and depression. He presented with increasing shortness of breath (SOB) over the past five days and was found to have 3+ mitral regurgitation (MR) on transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) with hemodynamics consistent with cardiogenic shock. The patient was subsequently intubated and an intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP) was placed.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's current condition is cardiogenic shock, which is characterized by reduced cardiac output and inadequate tissue perfusion. This can lead to organ dysfunction and failure if not appropriately managed.
2. Atrial flutter: The patient had an EKG showing sinus tachycardia, but there was a suspicion of atrial flutter. Conversion to normal sinus rhythm is crucial to prevent further complications.
3. Coronary artery disease: The patient may have underlying coronary artery disease, which could contribute to his current cardiogenic shock state. Further evaluation with cardiac catheterization is recommended.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient required intubation and mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. Weaning off the ventilator will be challenging given his unstable hemodynamics and the need for cardiac catheterization.

Summary:
Summary of the patient's progress note:
- The patient is a 53-year-old male with a history of obesity, obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), and depression.
- He presented with increasing shortness of breath (SOB) and was found to have moderate to severe mitral regurgitation (MR) on transthoracic echocardiography (TTE).
- The patient's hemodynamics are consistent with cardiogenic shock, and he has been intubated and placed on intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP) support.
- His ejection fraction (EF) is 20% with signs of diastolic dysfunction on TTE, indicating impaired left ventricular function.
- The patient's coronary arteries are clean, making ischemic cardiomyopathy unlikely.
- Biomarkers for myocardial injury are flat, and ROMI (rapid oxygen consumption monitoring) is complete.
- The patient is currently receiving amiodarone for tachycardia, lasix and diuril for fluid management, and heparin gtt for anticoagulation.
- The patient's acid-base status is complicated by contraction alkalosis with superimposed respiratory acidosis.
- Liver function tests (LFTs) are improving, but there is a concern for acute tubular necrosis (ATN) due to cardiogenic shock.
- The patient's creatinine level has improved to 1.5 today.
- The patient has a central venous pressure

Iron studies do not support hemochromatosis, and human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) status is pending.

- Consider weaning milrinone and continue IABP at 1:1.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 53-year-old male with a history of obesity, obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), and depression. He presented with increasing shortness of breath for five days and was found to have moderate-to-severe mitral regurgitation on transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE). The patient has been intubated and placed on intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP) support due to cardiogenic shock. His ejection fraction is 20% with signs of diastolic dysfunction on TTE. Coronary angiography showed clean coronaries, making ischemic cardiomyopathy unlikely. The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, and he has a fever, which could indicate an infection. Other labs indicate elevated liver enzymes, kidney dysfunction, and electrolyte imbalances. The patient's acid-base status is in contraction alkalosis with superimposed respiratory acidosis. The plan is to wean from milrinone and continue IABP support, monitor Fick Q change of shift, and continue the cardiomyopathy workup. The patient's tachycardia appears to be sinus tachycardia, and amiodarone will be continued. Lasix and diuril will be used to improve volume status and renal artery geometry. An electrophysiology consult has been requested. The patient's respiratory failure is due to fluid overload, and he will be trialed on pressure support (PS) today

   53yo male with history of obesity, OSA, and depression who p/w
   increasing SOB x5d and found to have 3+ MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 4298**] TTE with
   hemodynamics consistent with cardiogenic shock. Now s/p intubation and
   IABP placement
   .
   # Cardiogenic shock:: CI improved to 3 from 2.4 last night, but this is
   in the setting of fevers and tachycardia which could represent
   infection.  EF 20% with signs of diastolic dysfunction on TTE. LV and
   RV with global hypokinesis. Clean coronaries make ischemic
   cardiomyopathy unlikely. Cardiomyopathy workup underway. ESR 21. TSh
   normal. RF neg. [**Doctor First Name **] neg. Iron studies not consistent with
   hemochromatosis. HIV pending.
   - Will consider weaning milirone and continue IABP at 1;1
   - Monitor Fick Q change of shift and with change in clinical status
   - continue cardiomyopathy work up.
   .
   # Tachycardia: EKG c/w Sinus tach this am. Appeared to convert after
   dopamine stopped yesterday. Plan to continue amiodarone and try to
   improve volume status with lasix and diuril to help improve RA
   geometry. Some initial concern for sepsis given reduced SVR, fevers and
   tachycardia.
   - Continue Amiodarone
   - Continue heparin gtt
   .
   # Fever: Will culture today and repeat CXR. Concern for VAP/HAP so will
   start anbx coverage. Abd exam benign.
   - Start Vanco 1 g Q12 and Zosyn 4.5 q8
   - Will d/c swan line and culture tip
   .
   # Hypernatremia: Likely due to low volume. Free water deficit roughly 4
   liters. Will replete
 deficit with D5W.
   - Start 125 cc /hr D5w for 1.5 L
   .
   # Coronaries: Biomarkers flat. ROMI complete. Coronaries clean on
   Cath.
   - Will reduce ASA to 81 for primary prevention
   # Respiratory failure: Intubated [**7-9**] peri-cardioversion. Fluid status
   improved now.
   - Will trial with PS today
   .
   # Acid base status: Continues to have contraction alkalosis with
   superimposed respiratory acidosis. Will goal I/o even today and replete
   free water as above.
   .
   # Transaminitis: suspect shock liver. LFTs improving. INR elevated but
   stable.
   .  Trend daily INR, glucose, and ALT/AST.
   .
   # ARF: Suspect ATN in setting of cardiogenic shock as noted above. Cr
   improved to 1.5 today.
   # FEN: On TFs. Appreciate nutrition input. .
   .
   # ACCESS: Cordis with Swan and IJ access. A line. Peripherals
   .
   # Proph: Hep gtt, bowel regimen, HISS
   .
   # Pain control: appears comfortable
   .
   # Code: full
   .
   # Contact; Wife [**Telephone/Fax (1) 6146**] is HCP
   .
   # Dispo: CCU
   ICU Care

Summary:
The patient is a 53-year-old male with a history of obesity, obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), and depression. He presented with increasing shortness of breath (SOB) and was found to have moderate-to-severe mitral regurgitation (MR) on transthoracic echocardiography (TTE). The patient is currently in cardiogenic shock, as indicated by low cardiac index (CI) and signs of diastolic dysfunction on TTE. The left and right ventricles show global hypokinesis, and the coronaries are clean, making ischemic cardiomyopathy unlikely. Cardiomyopathy workup is ongoing, and the patient has negative rheumatoid factor (RF) and ESR 21.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient's CI improved to 3 from 2.4 last night, but this is in the setting of fevers and tachycardia, which could represent infection. Monitoring Fick Q change of shift and with change in clinical status is important.

2. Tachycardia: The patient has sinus tachycardia, which appeared to convert after dopamine was stopped yesterday. Plan to continue amiodarone and try to improve volume status with Lasix and diuril to help improve RA geometry.

3. Fever: The patient has a fever, and cultures will be done today. There is concern for ventilator-associated pneumonia (

   due to reduced tachycardia and elevated MAPs.  Interestingly MAPs
   higher since dopamine stopped yesterday. Elevated PA and PCWP with low
   pulmonary vascular resistance further support cardiogenic shock.
   - Increase Milrinone  to 2.5 to reduce MAPs and impove ionotropy
   - Lasix gtt for diuresis given fluid overload. Will bolus with Diuril
   500 mg IVx1 this am after such good response yesterday.
   - Monitor Fick Q change of shift and with change in clinical status
   - Repeat TTE today
   - Complete Cardiomyopathy work up
   - CHF consult today
   .

   dopamine stopped yesterday. Plan to continue amiodarone and try to
   improve volume status with lasix and diuril to help improve RA
   geometry.
   - Continue Amiodarone. Patient 900 mg into load as of 6 pm last night.
   - Continue heparin gtt
   - Plan to use lasix and diuril for goal I/O negative 1 L.
   -  [**Last Name (un) 6202**] EP consult for now
   .
